statement:
Let $X$ be a uniformly convex Banach space. Let $(x_n)$ be a sequence in
$X$ such that $\lim x_n= x$ in the weak-topology $(w(X,X^*))$ and
$\limsup \|x_n\|\leq \|x\|$.Then $x_n$ converges to $x$.

For $x=0$ the claim is obvious, so suppose that $x\neq 0$.The sequence
$({x_n})_{n\geq 1}$ converges to $x$ for $w-topology$
$\Rightarrow \|x\|\leq \liminf\|x_n\|$.So let
$\lambda_n=\max\{ \|x\|,\|x_n\|\}$ and we have that
$\lim\lambda_n= \|x\|$. Define $y_n=\frac{x_n}{\lambda_n}$ and
$y=\frac{x}{\|x\|}$.Then $y_n$ converges to $y$ in $w-topology$. We
conclude that $\|y\|\leq {\liminf{\|\frac{y_n+y}{2}\|}}$. Also,
$\|y\|=1, \|y_n\|\leq 1$ so we have that $\lim\|\frac{y_n+y}{2}\|=1$. As
the Banach space is uniformly convex one can easily see that
$\lim\|y_n-y\|=0 $. Therefore $x_n$ converges to $x$. The proof is
complete.
names: property of uniformly convex Banach Space
